article.title: Improving the Simulation of Quark and Gluon Jets with Herwig 7

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Dalitz plot in Figure 2 represent for the process e⁺e¯ → qāg?
choices: The distribution of jet masses after hadronization.
The probability of gluon emission as a function of quark and antiquark energies.
The allowed phase space for one gluon emission in an angular-ordered parton shower.
The momentum fractions of the quark and antiquark after hadronization.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the region marked as "dead-zone" in Figure 3?
choices: It represents the region where gluon emission is forbidden due to energy-momentum conservation.
It highlights the region where the parton shower overestimates the gluon emission probability.
It shows the area where hadronization effects dominate, making perturbative calculations unreliable.
It indicates the phase space region not populated by single gluon emissions from the parton shower in an angular-ordered approach.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the parameter Qg represent in the context of Equation 7?
choices: The energy scale at which the strong coupling constant is evaluated.
The minimum invariant mass required for a cluster to undergo fission.
The virtuality threshold for parton shower emissions, parameterized for different quark flavors.
The probability of a colour-singlet gluon jet production through colour reconnection.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is generally observed in the values of AlphaMZ (CMW (Mz)) across different tuning variations?
choices: Values are consistently lower for pT cut-off compared to virtual mass cut-off.
Values are generally higher when the virtuality (q²) of the branching is preserved.
Values are significantly affected by the inclusion of low-energy charged multiplicity data.
There is no clear trend in the values of AlphaMZ across different tuning variations.
